conclusion: Analysis of Ideal Gas Temperature Increase: Analyze the graphs showing the pressure and volume changes as a function of temperature for an ideal gas, and determine the pressure at 600 K.
From the p-T graph: At T = 200 K, p = 0.5 × 10³ Pa = 500 Pa
From the p-T graph: At T = 400 K, p = 1.0 × 10³ Pa = 1000 Pa
From the V-T graph: At T = 400 K, V = 2.5 m³
From the V-T graph: At T = 500 K, V = 2.7 m³
From the V-T graph: At T = 600 K, V = 3.0 m³
For an ideal gas, PV = nRT where P = pressure, V = volume, n = number of moles (constant), R = gas constant, T = temperature. For a fixed amount of gas, PV/T = nR = constant.

premise: Using T = 400 K, p = 1000 Pa, V = 2.5 m³
conclusion: Calculate nR: nR = PV/T = (1000 Pa × 2.5 m³)/400 K = 6.25 Pa·m³/K

premise: Using nR = 6.25 Pa·m³/K, T = 600 K, V = 3.0 m³
conclusion: Calculate pressure at 600 K: P = (6.25 Pa·m³/K × 600 K)/3.0 m³ = 1250 Pa = 1.25 × 10³ Pa

premise: Using nR = 6.25 Pa·m³/K, T = 500 K, V = 2.7 m³
conclusion: Verification: P = (6.25 Pa·m³/K × 500 K)/2.7 m³ ≈ 1157 Pa
The pressure of the gas when the temperature is 600 K is 1.25 × 10³ Pa or 1250 Pa.
